title: 112_s3614
content: The Act may be cited as the "Housing Assistance for Veterans Act of 2012" or the "HAVEN Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. In this Act, "disabled" refers to an individual with a disability as defined by section 12102 of title 42, United States Code. "Eligible veteran" means a disabled or low-income veteran. "Energy efficient features or equipment" include insulation, weatherstripping, air sealing, heating system repairs, duct sealing, or other measures to reduce electricity usage in a primary residence. "Low-income veteran" is a veteran whose income does not exceed 80 percent of the median income for an area. "Nonprofit organization" is also defined in the Act. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to an organization described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code and exempt from tax. A "primary residence" is defined as a dwelling owned by an eligible veteran or their family member, including a spouse, child, grandchild, parent, or sibling. The term "qualified organization" refers to a nonprofit organization that primarily serves veterans or low-income individuals. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The term "veteran" has the same meaning as in section 101 of title 38, United States Code. A "veterans service organization" is also defined. A "veterans service organization" is defined as any organization recognized by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for representing veterans under section 5902 of title 38, United States Code. Establishment of a pilot program. The Secretary will establish a pilot program to grant funds to organizations for rehabilitating eligible veterans' primary residences. The maximum grant amount per organization is $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Organizations must apply to the Secretary for funding. The Secretary requires organizations to submit applications with detailed plans for outreach initiatives, the number of veterans to be served, types of work to be conducted, and collaboration with the Department of Veterans Affairs and veterans service organizations. The Secretary requires organizations to submit applications with detailed plans for outreach initiatives, the number of veterans to be served, types of work to be conducted, and collaboration with the Department of Veterans Affairs and veterans service organizations. Preferences are given to organizations with experience in providing housing rehabilitation and modification services for disabled veterans or proposing to do so for eligible veterans in rural areas. Qualified organizations must demonstrate expertise in providing housing rehabilitation and modification services for disabled or low-income individuals. Qualified organizations applying for the pilot program must have outreach initiatives engaging eligible veterans and veteran service organizations, a network of nonprofit affiliates providing housing rehabilitation services, and experience in carrying out such services successfully. Qualified organizations applying for the pilot program must have experience in accountability and reporting for grant funds, including those from private or government entities. Grant funds are used to modify and rehabilitate eligible veterans' primary residences, which may include installing wheelchair ramps, widening doors, reconfiguring bathrooms, and adding lighting and electrical outlets. The pilot program aims to modify and rehabilitate eligible veterans' primary residences by accommodating disabilities, reducing fall risks for the elderly, rehabilitating disrepair, and installing energy-efficient features for veterans with high utility costs. The pilot program aims to modify and rehabilitate eligible veterans' primary residences by accommodating disabilities, reducing fall risks for the elderly, rehabilitating disrepair, and installing energy-efficient features to reduce costs. The Secretary will oversee grant funds to ensure efficient use for addressing veterans' adaptive housing needs, and matching funds may be required. The pilot program requires qualified organizations to contribute at least 50% of the grant award towards housing modifications for eligible veterans. Veterans should not pay more than 30% of their income in housing costs after modifications are made. In-kind contributions can be arranged to meet the funding requirement. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the pilot program, including the number of veterans assisted, their demographics, entities contracted, funds raised, and housing rehabilitation details. The annual report to Congress on the pilot program must include details on housing rehabilitation and modification services provided, outreach initiatives by the Secretary and grant recipients, and any other relevant information for program assessment. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress within 6 months after the pilot program's completion, providing relevant information for program assessment. $4,000,000 is authorized for carrying out the Act annually from 2013 to 2017.
